narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better understanding of calculus of one variable.

I have gained an understanding of how to execute and utilize various calculus practices including polar equations, parametric equations, integration and derivatives, calculation of areas of volumes, and convergence of series.
techniques for antiderivatives
Calc lol
How to combine separate pieces of math knowledge to solve problems
I leaned a lot of basic single variable calculus skills and problem solving.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength of the class is the corresponding website that had notes from the class and the class sessions available. I think putting more effort into engaging students would go a long way.

The peer tutoring helped so much. Also, I felt very supported for all exams with the review sessions and practice exams. It was also incredibly organized and well-structured. The pace was also very nice.

The testing procedures could be improved, considering some students are remote from home. Not everyone lives in the same kind of households where we can have our mics unmuted for two hours.

This class would really benefit from more peer tutors/office hours in more days throughout the week. I found when I had questions I would have to wait days to have them answered because of how few tutoring resources were available, which negatively impacted my work. 

Also, it would be very appreciated if explanations to the explore/concept checks/problem sets were posted after the due date to learn how to do the material since peer tutors weren't always available.

Strength: Psests
Weaknesses: Test format could be odd considering how we practiced in psets

The level of teaching varies greatly, and it's unfortunate for those who are placed in sections with less-than-great instructors. Not sure why the classes are set up to have so many instructors teach small classes. I think it'd be better to have larger classes if that means more students have access to better instructors. Newer or less experienced instructors can listen in on these classes, but not teach them until they can match that high level of instruction.
I think that the daily lectures could be more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Peer tutoring was so helpful. In class breakout rooms were a little awkward and didn't really add to the learning experience.
I appreciated the concept checks, but I feel that they would have been more beneficial if answers with explanations were available after the due date!
Course was modeled well
Recorded review sessions - please continue to do this!
I think the instructor did the best that he could during this time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would because it was a good refresher course from my senior year high school math, but there were a lot of things that I didn't like about the class, but I would still recommend.
Yes because it is challenging, but you learn a lot.
Not for anyone who has taken Calculus BC in highschool and felt comfortable in the material - go ahead and take MATH 120!
Yes
No I would not. The midterms and final were unnecessarily difficult. It was clear that the students best interest and improvement was not prioritized.
Yes, the course is well organized and has many practice resources available.
Yes it was a good course for STEM and math students.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We were allowed to stop and ask questions. Additionally, we sometimes broke off into breakout rooms to do group work.
none
N/a
It was primarily live lectures with office hours available.
